history.content: If you just want to pass the class, 5-7 hrs/wk is probably ok. In fact, I'll say 137A is probably the easiest physics upper div as long as you have strong knowledge of linear algebra. Other courses rely heavily on vector calculus and the problem sets get very tedious.

children.subject: Thanks! Did you take the course with Prof. Kasen by any chance? How long would you say you spent on the weekly HW, and what was your math/physics background going into the class?

I took Physics 5C with Prof. Kasen. He is one of the best physics professors I had. He can explain concepts well and very friendly.

I took 137A with Prof Siddiqi. HW is around 4-5 questions, most of them are not too difficult (~4 hrs per week). 137A is definitely on the easy side for upper div physics. If you put some effort, 137A shouldn't be a problem.

history.content:
If anyone has taken Physics 137A (Quantum Mechanics) before, approximately how many hours/week should I reasonably expect to spend on this class in order to receive a passing grade? Would 5 hrs/wk be reasonable? I have an OK, but not great, background in the prerequisite material (Physics 7A, 7B, Math 54, and a bit of Math 110). Daniel Kasen is teaching it this semester if that matters.
I'm looking for a low-workload natural science elective to take this semester, and I chose 137A because it seemed interesting and I don't mind P/NPing it, but I just want to make sure I'm able to pass because I need to graduate. If 137A is too hard, does anyone have recommendations on an easy natural science elective that's available in Sp21?
Thanks!
history.subject: Workload for Physics 137A?
